content: I've done almost all of Lemma 5.4.7 (the old 5.4.8) at https://github.com/fpvandoorn/carleson/pull/93
There is, however, a blocker sorry: I cannot seem to prove ùî∞ p + (Z * (n + 1) : ‚Ñï) ‚â§ ùî∞ q. The problem is that ‚Ñ≠‚ÇÉ k n j might look like this:
20240726_184253.jpg

The chosen q ‚Äì just a maximal element of the set in (5.4.9) ‚Äì might have only p below it in ‚Ñ≠‚ÇÉ k n j, and in that case I cannot conclude the required inequality ùî∞ p + (Z * (n + 1) : ‚Ñï) ‚â§ ùî∞ q
While I can prove that there exist Z * (n + 1) distinct elements in a chain above p, I cannot prove that the top of the chain (depicted in the picture) is actually q!
@Floris van Doorn I had to take a break from Lean, but see above

Ah, you introduced a MinLayer abstraction; I guess this overlaps with Task 52. I‚Äôll make sure to continue my work off your PR, I guess?

Would it help if you had a lemma that, given (ha : q ‚àà A.minLayer n) gives you a s : LTSeries (‚Ñ≠‚ÇÉ k n j) such that ‚àÉ i, s i ‚àà A.minLayer i and (in particular)s n = q?
The statements in your message don't make sense even after the edits

I spent a whole day trying to prove an "intermediate value theorem", that given any set of tiles, tile p in minLayer m, tile q in minLayer n, p <= q, m <= l <= n, there is a tile in minLayer l between p and q. I then realised that was false, as shown in the pic above
Ah, I see. Yes, I‚Äôm barking up the wrong tree, ignore the above :-)

(I was wrongly assuming that the q might be the one obtained from

lemma exists_le_add_scale_of_mem_layersBelow (hp : p ‚àà A.layersBelow n) :
‚àÉ p' ‚àà A.maxLayer 0, p ‚â§ p' ‚àß ùî∞ p + n ‚â§ ùî∞ p'

or similar, and in that case that lemma could maybe be strenghtend to give you not just p' as q, but a full series with one element in each layer.)
You nailed it; that is a huge gap in the blueprint proof
Ah, ok. So maybe I am not competely off? I was planing to provide the stronger lemma as part of Task 52.
Try and work it out yourself. There might be some other property of tiles that makes the stronger lemma true
Or C_3 k n j

20240727_115013.jpg
Yeah, the blueprint proof of forest-inner is wrong
For simplicity Z * (n + 1) = 5 here, but this is a collection of seven tiles that could be C_3 k n j
Here the scales of the cubes underlying the tiles increase by 1 per step as you go up, I(q) is the third cube from top in the left diagram
r and q are maximal tiles, and are indeed not related by the partial order on tiles

Jeremy Tan said:

20240726_184253.jpg

This picture cannot happen. On the side of the grids there must be cubes in between at every level, see carleson#Grid.exists_unique_succ and carleson#Grid.scale_succ.
Then at the level of tiles biUnion_Œ© shows that all these intermediate cubes have corresponding tiles, and together with relative_fundamental_dyadic (and cball_subset) shows that these tiles are actually between the two elements.
Finally, since C_3 is order connected, these tiles all live in C_3.

Does this make sense? It seems that there are some steps missing in the proof.
But are you saying that you can finish the proof more easily using exists_le_add_scale_of_mem_layersBelow ?

Floris van Doorn said:

Jeremy Tan said:

20240726_184253.jpg

This picture cannot happen. On the side of the grids there must be cubes in between at every level, see carleson#Grid.exists_unique_succ and carleson#Grid.scale_succ.
Then at the level of tiles biUnion_Œ© shows that all these intermediate cubes have corresponding tiles, and together with relative_fundamental_dyadic (and cball_subset) shows that these tiles are actually between the two elements.
Finally, since C_3 is order connected, these tiles all live in C_3.

Does this make sense? It seems that there are some steps missing in the proof.
But are you saying that you can finish the proof more easily using exists_le_add_scale_of_mem_layersBelow ?

This picture can happen, see https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/442935-Carleson/topic/Task.2052/near/454417371

The left chain of elements is the one obtained from exists_le_add_scale_of_mem_layersBelow, but the top element of that chain and q being in the maximum layer is no guarantee that they are related as tiles

Call the top tile of the left chain r and assume r != q. Then I know well that I(r) and I(q) are related since they both contain I(p), and that Œ© r and Œ© q are disjoint since r and q are distinct maximals in C_3 k n j, hence not related as tiles
But I cannot rule out the possibility that s(q)<s(r)

and indeed I (believe I have) constructed in the other stream a counterexample to the claim that s(p) + Z * (n + 1) <= s(q), a counterexample that is compatible with all the constraints on grids, tiles and C_3/C_4
The crux of the problem seems to be that p in layersBelow expresses a lower bound on the longest, not shortest path to a maximal element
23 messages were moved here from #Carleson > Outstanding Tasks, V3 by Floris van Doorn.
Ok, I've asked Lars to take a look.
Lars updated the proof in the blueprint, which is live now.
@Floris van Doorn I have fixed the PR I made initially for forest-inner https://github.com/fpvandoorn/carleson/pull/93
And linked my minLayer to Breitner's height
Thanks!
Jeremy Tan has marked this topic as resolved.
